channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2021 The New York Times Company

item.title: Modi to Repeal India Farm Laws Following Protests
item.description: A bungled response to Covid and a struggling economy have hurt his party’s standing, leaving it vulnerable to a well-organized protest movement.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall, Karan Deep Singh and Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: Farmers last December near tents set up in the middle of a highway as part of protests, which would turn out to go on for a year, against the Indian government’s new farm laws.

item.title: Why India's Farmers Are Protesting
item.description: The government withstood months of protest, with both sides refusing to compromise, before it unexpectedly bowed to the farmers’ demands this week.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal, Emily Schmall and Russell Goldman
item.media:description: Indian farmers in a tractor rally in New Delhi in January to protest new agricultural laws. The protests persisted for months, and this week the government backed down.

item.title: Austria Announces Covid Vaccine Mandate, Crossing a Threshold for Europe
item.description: The extraordinary step shows that governments desperate to safeguard public health and economic recoveries are increasingly willing to push for once unthinkable measures.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Melissa Eddy
item.media:description: People lined up outside Saint Stephen’s Cathedral in Vienna Friday to receive Covid-19 vaccinations after Chancellor Alexander Schallenberg announced a mandatory vaccination against the coronavirus by February 2022 and a general nationwide lockdown to stem the pandemic.

item.title: On Putin’s Strategic Chessboard, a Series of Destabilizing Moves
item.description: In the stretch of Europe from the Baltic Sea to the Black Sea, where Moscow and the West have competed for influence for decades, the threat of a new military conflict is growing.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia speaking at a memorial dedicated to the end of the Russian civil war this month in Sevastopol, Crimea.

item.title: Amazon Deforestation Soars to 15-Year High
item.description: Brazil committed this month to end illegal deforestation in eight years, but a government report raises questions about its intent and ability to meet that target.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Andreoni
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: A deforested area of the Amazon rainforest in Pará State in August 2020.

item.title: Venezuelan Opposition Risks an Election Challenge to Maduro
item.description: With little hope of a fair vote, opposition candidates take a desperate risk to gain any edge against Venezuela’s entrenched autocrat, Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz and Adriana Loureiro Fernandez
item.media:description: Américo De Grazia, an opposition candidate running for the governor’s office of Bolivar state, taking a call this month at his party’s headquarters.

item.title: China’s Influence Looms Over Blinken’s Africa Visit
item.description: On a stop in Nigeria, the secretary of state said the U.S. would no longer treat African countries as pawns in a global game. But American competition with Beijing was hard to overlook.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: After Time in U.S. Prisons, Maria Butina Now Sits in Russia's Parliament
item.description: Maria Butina, convicted of serving as an unregistered foreign agent before and after the 2016 election, insists she “wasn’t a spy” and that her Duma seat is “not a reward.” Her critics call her a Kremlin “trophy.”
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maria Butina, in a Moscow restaurant in October. She made headlines across America when she was convicted three years ago of operating as an unregistered foreign agent.

item.title: First Known Covid Case Was Vendor at Wuhan Market, Scientist Says
item.description: A new review of early Covid-19 cases in the journal Science will revive, though certainly not settle, the debate over how the pandemic began.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer, Benjamin Mueller and Chris Buckley
item.media:description: Medical staff assisted a Covid patient into an ambulance in Wuhan, China, in March 2020.

item.title: Strike on U.S. Base Was Iranian Response to Israeli Attack, Officials Say
item.description: Iran has not acknowledged the attack, but U.S. and Israeli officials said it was retaliation for Israeli airstrikes, drawing the U.S. into Iran’s shadow war with Israel.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and Ronen Bergman
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Five armed drones were launched at the American military base at Al Tanf, Syria, on Oct. 20.

item.title: Belarus Clears Migrant Camp, Easing Border Standoff With Poland
item.description: Throngs of people, mainly from the Mideast, who had been living in freezing conditions on the border, have been moved to a giant warehouse. Their fate is uncertain.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins and James Hill
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: The large and increasingly squalid encampment near Bruzgi on the Belarus-Poland border was cleared of migrants by Belarusian forces on Thursday.

item.title: China and U.S. Quietly Released Captive Citizens Before Summit
item.description: The moves seemed aimed at untangling diplomatic knots as the two countries are clashing over human rights abuses, economic policies and much more.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong and Katie Rogers
item.media:description: Daniel Hsu pictured in Shanghai in April 2020. He had been prevented for four years from leaving China.

item.title: Furor Over Peng Shuai's #Metoo Accusation Challenges China
item.description: The tennis world is outraged over the latest twist in a star player’s complaint of assault and abrupt disappearance from public life.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Steven Lee Myers
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.media:description: Peng Shuai at the Australian Open in Melbourne in January 2020.

item.title: In Welcoming Prince Charles, Egypt’s Leader Sends a Message
item.description: The prince and his wife, Camilla, made Egypt their first foreign destination since the pandemic. Vestiges of British colonialism aside, they saw something new.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:description: Prince Charles and Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall, in front of the Sphinx in Giza, Egypt, on Thursday.

item.title: Canada Keeps World Cup Dream Alive in Qualifying Match
item.description: The Canadian men’s team, which has not been in the World Cup since 1986, is now leading the regional qualifying competition.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Jason Franson/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Alistair Johnston celebrating Canada’s unexpected win over Mexico.

item.title: Canada Expands Vaccines Accepted for Travel
item.description: Officials also removed a test requirement for eligible travelers re-entering Canada within 72 hours.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Drivers crossing the United States-Canadian border in Blaine, Wash., in August. Travelers planning a trip of under 72 hours departing from Canada will no longer be required to take a coronavirus test to re-enter the country.

item.title: Canada Approves Pfizer's Covid Vaccine for Kids 5 to 11
item.description: The move adds more than 2.8 million young people to those eligible for a shot.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: The Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine is the first option approved in Canada for children 5 to 11 years old.

item.title: German Health Minister Won't Rule Out New Lockdown
item.description: The remarks came in response to a reporter’s question as neighboring Austria prepares to lock down and cases continue to reach record levels.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: A vaccination bus near Munich on Friday.

item.title: Why the U.S. Is Considering Expanding Booster Shot Eligibility to All Adults
item.description: The U.S. may soon offer booster shots to every adult. Here’s why.
item.dc:creator: Ian Prasad Philbrick and Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Ash Adams for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman receives a booster in Anchorage.

item.title: Japan Approves a $490 Billion Stimulus Package
item.description: The move, announced on Friday, is an attempt by the country’s newish prime minister to revive an economy battered by Covid restrictions and a supply chain crunch.
item.dc:creator: Hikari Hida
item.media:description: In Tokyo last month. Japan announced a partial easing of border restrictions this month and has already lifted most pandemic restrictions on its economy.

item.title: 1946: U.K. Launches Campaign for Roosevelt Statue
item.description: Prime Minister Clement Attlee announced a fund-raising drive to erect a statue of Franklin D. Roosevelt opposite the American embassy in London.
item.dc:creator: The International Herald Tribune

item.title: What Does Mateship Mean to You?
item.description: It’s a complicated, often-contested word that has evolved along with Australia’s values.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: People enjoying a picnic in Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, in September.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Tensions ease at the Poland-Belarus border.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants turned back from the border with Poland walked to a shelter in Belarus.

item.title: Cambodia Reopens for Fully Vaccinated Travelers
item.description: Tourism-dependent businesses have struggled to make ends meet without visitors.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Tang Chhin Sothy/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Angkor Wat temple in Siem Reap province, Cambodia, in 2020, may be seeing greater numbers of tourists as Cambodia is set to welcome vaccinated international tourists without quarantine.

item.title: The U.S. Army secretary to National Guard members who resist the vaccines: Prepare for discipline.
item.description: Remaining unvaccinated could cost soldiers promotions, bonuses or even their jobs.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Steinhauer
item.media:description: Members of the Oklahoma National Guard on the steps of the Senate on Capitol Hill in January.

item.title: Greece, Facing Surging Cases, Adds Restrictions for the Unvaccinated
item.description: Germany restricts access to public transportation, Austria will impose full lockdowns in two states, and the Netherlands recently restored mask mandates in some public indoor places.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: Medical workers protesting mandatory vaccinations and the indefinite suspension of healthcare employees who have not been vaccinated, in Athens, in early November.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Where do the migrants in Belarus go next?
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants walking from the Polish border to a warehouse shelter on Thursday in Belarus.

item.title: The Netherlands aims to keep its schools open, even as cases soar among young people.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: A school in Oosthuizen, the Netherlands, in August. The biggest increase in the number of new infections in the country was among children ages 4 to 12, according to government data.

item.title: Fury in Kashmir After Deadly Police Raid at Shopping Complex
item.description: Saying that the men killed in a gun battle were separatist militants or “terrorist supporters,” security forces initially refused to return the bodies to their families, but later relented and gave back two.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: Relatives and neighbors of men who were killed in a clash this week with the police in a shopping center in Srinagar, Kashmir.

item.title: 2 Austrian States, Including Salzburg, to Impose Covid Lockdowns
item.description: The state, along with neighboring Upper Austria, will apply the restrictions to everyone regardless of inoculation status. The moves come in the wake of national rules affecting unvaccinated people.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Police officers checking shoppers’ vaccination status at a store entrance in Vienna on Wednesday.

item.title: Elusive Migrants Leave Haunting Traces in Polish Forests
item.description: The migrants, themselves are elusive, but they leave behind evidence of the lives they left behind, and of their desperate bids to reach the European Union.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk

item.title: As Covid Rules Ease, Australian Open Can Play Before a Full House
item.description: The annual Boxing Day cricket test match in Melbourne will also be allowed to take place before a full-capacity crowd.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Novak Djokovic after winning the Australian Open men’s singles title in Melbourne in February.

item.title: Germany Moves to Impose New Covid Regulations
item.description: The measures include a rule that only those who are vaccinated, have recovered from an infection or test negative can ride public transit or attend work in person.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Commuting in Berlin this month. Germany reported yet another record in daily new Covid infections on Wednesday.

item.title: The Czech Republic prepares for new restrictions as cases soar.
item.dc:creator: Hana de Goeij
item.media:description: Protesting coronavirus restrictions in Prague on Wednesday during a commemoration of the 32nd anniversary of the Velvet Revolution.

item.title: How Biden's Spending Bill Will Change Healthcare
item.description: We’re looking at the ways Biden’s social policy bill will change health care.
item.dc:creator: Margot Sanger-Katz
item.media:credit: Ilana Panich-Linsman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A doctor examines a 10-year-old patient in Austin, Texas.

item.title: Plane Returning Migrants From Belarus Lands in Iraq
item.description: Unable to reach the European Union, the migrants returned to Iraq, but many said they would try again to emigrate, and thousands are still in Belarus.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf, Sangar Khaleel and Shashank Bengali
item.media:description: Iraqi migrants after a flight for voluntary evacuees from Belarus arrived in Erbil on Thursday.

item.title: India's Limit on Syringe Exports Hobbles Global Covid Vaccinations
item.description: The South Asian country is a major producer of the type of syringe used for coronavirus inoculations.
item.dc:creator: Karan Deep Singh
item.media:credit: Rebecca Conway for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers checking syringes at Hindustan Syringes and Medical Devices, one of the world’s largest syringe makers.

item.title: Sex Ed, One Instagram Post at a Time
item.description: Activists are using social media to do what Arab countries have failed to do: teach women about their bodies. They are aiming for nothing less than a cultural awakening.
item.dc:creator: Mona El-Naggar and Sara Aridi
item.media:credit: Heba Khamis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nour Emam, also known by the web handle “motherbeing,” hosts one of the leading platforms for sex education in the Arab world.

item.title: Must This Covid Swab Go So Far Up Your Nose?
item.description: Some testers gently swab the front of your nostril and send you on your way. Others dig deep, bringing the pain. What’s the gold standard?
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka and John Yoon
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: A Covid-19 test with a deep nasal swab in Seoul, South Korea.

item.title: At Summit, U.S., Canada and Mexico Avoid Thorny Questions
item.description: The meeting let North American leaders present a united front without going into detail on deeper issues, including trade disputes or migration.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers and Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:description: President Biden met with his counterparts from Canada and Mexico at the White House on Thursday. The leaders struck an agreement to share vaccines.

item.title: India's Toxic Air Pollution Prompts Supreme Court to Act
item.description: Schools and factories close. India’s Supreme Court blasts the government’s do-nothing response. But Delhi residents continue to suffer from the bad air.
item.dc:creator: Hari Kumar and Emily Schmall
item.media:description: New Delhi as it was engulfed in heavy smog last week.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Lukashenko’s risky border actions.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Children in Belarus on the border with Poland, which has been girded with razor wire, on Wednesday.

item.title: Munich’s Famed Christmas Market is Canceled Again
item.description: Munich’s is the largest German Christmas market to be canceled as the events struggle to survive the country’s fourth virus surge.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.media:description: The Christmas market in Munich in 2013. It has been canceled for a second straight year.

item.title: Biden Administration Plans to Expand Covid Vaccine Production
item.description: The Biden administration will spend billions of dollars on a new plan to combat the pandemic, investing in antiviral pills, rapid tests and manufacturing.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:credit: Mike Kai Chen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Activists have been demanding for months that Mr. Biden do more to scale up global vaccine manufacturing capacity.

item.title: Intractable African Crises Flare as Biden’s Top Diplomat Visits Kenya
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken hoped to ease the turmoil engulfing Sudan and Ethiopia in his first trip to sub-Saharan Africa. Both worsened on his first full day.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Declan Walsh
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken speaking in Nairobi, Kenya, on Wednesday.

item.title: Risk for Leader of Belarus: Migrants He Lured May Want to Stay
item.description: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus, whom the E.U. accuses of engineering a migrant crisis on the border with Poland, could face a serious headache if asylum seekers try to stay in his country.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants in Belarus on the border with Poland, which has been girded with razor wire, on Wednesday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Billions for more vaccine equity.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Mike Kai Chen for The New York Times
item.media:description: A 6-year-old getting his first dose of the Pfizer vaccine in San Francisco.

item.title: Egypt Prepares to Give Leaders Special Powers in Epidemics
item.description: Critics fear that the legislation will be just another avenue the government can use to crack down on dissent.
item.dc:creator: Nada Rashwan
item.media:description: People waiting to receive a Covid-19 vaccine at the Sadat Metro Station in Cairo on Sunday.

item.title: Boris Johnson Battered in Parliament as Scandal Puts Him on Defense
item.description: Reversals and broken promises have eroded his party’s lead in the polls, and the prime minister faces a low-grade mutiny from Conservatives angry over a proposal to limit their options for extra income.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain faces a furor over Conservative Party lawmakers taking lucrative outside work.

item.title: How the Belarus Standoff Is Unlike Recent Migrant Crises
item.description: The images at the Belarus-Poland border look familiar, but this emergency has little in common with previous waves of people from Syria, Myanmar and Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: Richard Pérez-Peña
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants camping on the Belarusian side of the border on Tuesday night.

item.title: Greece to Put Aid Workers Who Helped Migrants on Trial on Espionage Charges
item.description: The country’s conservative government is toughening its stance on migration and on groups working with migrants, aligning itself with a hardening climate across Europe.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers directing a raft of migrants off the Greek island of Lesbos in 2016.

item.title: Vaccinated vs. Unvaccinated: Europe’s Covid Culture War
item.description: In pockets of Europe, vaccine resistance has become the long tail of the populist nationalist movements that shook up European politics for a decade.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Lena Mucha for The New York Times

item.title: Beyond the Freezing Forest, a Green Light at the Window for Migrants
item.description: An unofficial network of local residents, activists and volunteer medics in Poland has been working to support those who have made it across from Belarus in bitter conditions.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maria Ancipuk, a resident of Michalowo, Poland, has placed a green light in a window to show migrants that her home is a safe place to ask for help.

item.title: As the pandemic spread, Americans died of drug overdoses in record numbers.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:credit: Hannah Yoon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tammy Adams at her home in Horsham, Pa., last April. Adams’s son, David, died in November 2020 from an overdose.

item.title: Raúl Rivero, Disenchanted Poet of the Cuban Revolution, Dies at 75
item.description: A leading journalistic voice who broke with the Castro regime, he gained wide recognition for his protests, was jailed as a dissident and went into exile.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts
item.media:description: The poet and journalist Raúl Rivero in 2005. A loyal supporter of the Cuban revolution, he later broke with President Fidel Castro and was jailed as a dissident.

item.title: Doppa, a Central Asian Hat, Guides Quest for Uyghur Roots
item.description: For an Australian woman with roots in Central Asia, a growing awareness of her heritage and the peril her people face all began with an embroidered skullcap.
item.dc:creator: Aina J. Khan
item.media:credit: Isabella Moore for The New York Times
item.media:description: Subhi Bora, who was born in Sydney, Australia, to a Uyghur mother and Uzbek father, traveled to Uzbekistan in search of a doppa, a traditional hat, as a way to reconnect with her heritage.

item.title: Liverpool Bomber Had Planned for Months, U.K. Police Say
item.description: The authorities named the man they believe to be behind an explosion in a taxi outside a hospital, who was also the only person killed, as Emad Al Swealmeen, 32.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Police officers working at the site of the explosion outside Liverpool Women's Hospital in northwestern England on Wednesday.
